synopsis: A billionaire heiress goes undercover as an intern. A coworker falls for her and proposes — but vanishes when he learns who she really is. She brings him back, and they have "the wedding of the century." Three years later, divorce rumors begin...

contents.translation: People called it the wedding of the century.

grammar.explanation: Quotation particle, used to quote what someone said
Attached to verbs to indicate multiple people did the action

contents.culture: Korean media dramatizes marriages between chaebols and commoners as 'weddings of the century' due to the extreme social status gap.

contents.original: 대한민국 최고 재벌의 딸과 신입사원의 결혼이라니.
contents.pronunciation: Daehanminguk choego jaebeol-ui ttal-gwa sinipsawon-ui gyeolhon-irani.
contents.translation: A marriage between Korea's top chaebol's daughter and a new employee, can you believe it?

grammar.example: 딸과 신입사원 = daughter and new employee
결혼이라니 = can you believe it's a marriage?

contents.culture: Chaebol (재벌) refers to powerful family-owned conglomerates like Samsung or Hyundai. Class-crossing marriages are a staple K-drama theme.

contents.translation: It's already been 3 years.

grammar.explanation: Already - expresses surprise at time passing quickly
To become, to reach a state or amount
Ending expressing mild surprise or realization

contents.translation: It feels like just yesterday, you know.

grammar.explanation: Day before yesterday, but idiomatically means 'just recently'
Connective ending meaning 'but' or giving background
Filler phrase seeking agreement, like 'you know'

contents.original: 남들은 재벌가에 입성한 기분이 어떠냐, 여왕과 결혼해 사는 건 어떤 거냐 물어들 보는데요.
contents.pronunciation: Namdeureun jaebolgae ipseonghan gibuni eotteonya, yeowang-gwa gyeolhonhae saneun geon eotteon geonya mureodeul boneundeyo.
contents.translation: People ask me how it feels to join a chaebol family, what it's like being married to a queen.

grammar.explanation: Casual question ending in indirect speech
Nominalizer, turns verb into 'the thing of doing'
grammar.example: 사는 건 = the thing of living / living

contents.culture: Calling a wealthy heiress '여왕' (queen) reflects how Koreans perceive chaebol daughters as royalty in modern society.

contents.translation: Well, would you believe me if I said this?

contents.original: 전 그저 사랑하는 여자를 만나 함께 살고 있는 운 좋은 남자일 뿐이라는 것.
contents.pronunciation: Jeon geujeo saranghaneun yeojareul manna hamkke salgo inneun un joheun namja-il ppun-iraneun geot.
contents.translation: I'm just a lucky guy who met the woman I love and lives with her.

grammar.explanation: To be nothing but, to be just/only
grammar.example: 남자일 뿐 = just a man, nothing more

contents.original: 백현우 씨가 저랑 결혼한 게 재벌이라 그렇다.
contents.pronunciation: Baek Hyeonwu ssi-ga jeorang gyeolhonhan ge jaebol-ira geureota.
contents.translation: They say Baek Hyeonwoo married me because I'm a chaebol.

grammar.explanation: Honorific title, like Mr./Ms., used after names

contents.translation: He only married for money.

grammar.example: 돈만 보고 = looking only at money
결혼한 거다 = (the fact is) he married

contents.culture: In Korea, marriages involving wealth disparity often face public suspicion of being 'gold-digging' relationships.

contents.original: 정말 별의별 말들이 많았던 걸로 알아요.
contents.pronunciation: Jeongmal byeol-uibyeol maldeuri manhatdeon geollo arayo.
contents.translation: I know there were all kinds of rumors.

grammar.explanation: All sorts of, various kinds of (often negative)
grammar.example: 별의별 말 = all kinds of talk/rumors

grammar.explanation: To know/understand that something was the case
grammar.example: 많았던 걸로 알아요 = I know there were many

contents.original: 그건 제가 여러 가지 이유로 얼굴을 공개하지 않아서 그런 소문이 돌았던 거고.
contents.pronunciation: Geugeon jega yeoreo gaji iyuro eolgureul gongghae-haji anaseo geureon somuni doratdeon geogo.
contents.translation: That's because I didn't reveal my face for various reasons, so those rumors spread.
contents.culture: Korean celebrities and chaebol family members often hide their identities or faces to avoid public scrutiny.

contents.translation: Starting today, all those rumors will disappear.
Since I'm revealing my face like this.

contents.original: 부부 생활 뭐 다 비슷하지 않을까 싶기는 한데.
contents.pronunciation: Bubu saenghwal mwo da biseuthaji aneulkka sipgineun hande.
contents.translation: I think married life is probably all similar, but...

grammar.explanation: I think/wonder if it might be
grammar.example: 비슷하지 않을까 싶다 = I think it might be similar
싶기는 한데 = I do think so, but...

contents.original: 아침에 그 사람과 함께 눈을 뜨고 같이 밥을 먹고 물론 출근길도 함께고요.
contents.pronunciation: Achime geu saram-gwa hamkke nuneul tteugo gachi babeul meokgo mullon chulgeun-gildo hamkkegoyo.
contents.translation: In the morning, I wake up with that person, eat together, and of course commute together too.

grammar.example: 그 사람과 함께 = together with that person

grammar.explanation: To open one's eyes, to wake up

grammar.example: 물론 출근길도 = of course the commute too

contents.translation: You're asking how it feels to be together from morning to night?

grammar.example: 아침부터 밤까지 = from morning to night

grammar.explanation: Quoting a question someone asked, 'you're asking if...?'
grammar.example: 어떠냐고요 = you're asking how it is?

contents.translation: I'm happy every day.

contents.original: 저는 5년 전에 유학에서 돌아와서 당시 제 아버지가 대표로 계시던 퀸즈백화점에 인턴으로 들어가게 됐어요.
contents.pronunciation: Jeoneun o-nyeon jeone yuhak-eseo dorawaseo dangsi je abeojiga daepyoro gyesideon Kwinjeu-baekhwajeome inteon-euro deureogage dwaesseoyo.
contents.translation: Five years ago, I returned from studying abroad and joined Queens Department Store, where my father was the CEO at the time, as an intern.

grammar.example: 유학에서 돌아오다 = return from studying abroad

grammar.explanation: To come to, to end up (happening)

contents.culture: Korean chaebols often have their children work as undercover interns to learn the business from the ground up before taking leadership roles.

contents.translation: Kind of like an undercover, you could say.

grammar.explanation: A kind of, a sort of
grammar.example: 일종의 언더커버 = a kind of undercover

grammar.explanation: Shall I say, you could call it

contents.translation: We know that feeling, right?

grammar.explanation: You know, as you know (assuming shared knowledge)

contents.translation: Ah, this guy likes me.
So that's why he's sending signals.
contents.culture: 시그널 (signal) is Konglish commonly used in Korean dating culture to describe subtle hints of romantic interest.

contents.translation: No, that wasn't it.
Because she kept kicking the copy machine.
I got worried.
Why? Why? Why?
The copy machine.

contents.original: 근데 몇 번 더 도와주다 보니까
contents.pronunciation: Geunde myeot beon deo dowajuda bonikka
contents.translation: But after helping a few more times...

grammar.explanation: After doing something repeatedly, as a result of

contents.translation: I became worried about that woman.
And when she hit the backspace...

contents.original: 그 당시 왠지 인상이 인턴으로 들어왔다고 회사의 소문이 자자해서 틀림없이 금방 잘릴 것 같았거든요.
contents.pronunciation: Geu dangsi waenji insangi inteon-euro deureowatdago hoesaui somuni jajahae-seo teullim-eopsi geumbang jallil geot gatatgeodeunyo.
contents.translation: At that time, there were lots of rumors at the company about some impressive intern, and I thought she would definitely get fired soon.

contents.pronunciation: Hong Hyein ssi jinjja eojjeoryeogo geureomnikka.
contents.translation: Hong Hyein, what are you trying to do?

grammar.explanation: What are you going to do, what's your plan
grammar.example: 어쩌려고 그래 = what are you thinking?

grammar.explanation: Formal form of 그래요, asking 'why are you doing that?'
grammar.example: 그럽니까 = why do you do that? (formal)

contents.translation: I know because I've done a lot of part-time jobs.
contents.culture: 알바 (alba) comes from the German word 'Arbeit' (work). It's commonly used in Korea and Japan for part-time work.

contents.pronunciation: Hong Hyein ssi geureoda geu jallim-nida.
contents.translation: Hong Hyein, you'll get fired if you keep that up.

grammar.explanation: If you keep doing that, at this rate
grammar.example: 그러다 = if you keep doing that

grammar.explanation: To get fired, to be cut (passive)

contents.translation: I don't care if I get fired.

grammar.example: 잘래도 = even if I get fired

grammar.explanation: It doesn't matter, I don't care

contents.translation: Of course you don't care. You can just go somewhere else.

grammar.explanation: I suppose, probably (with slight sarcasm here)
grammar.example: 상관없겠죠 = I suppose you don't care
딴 데 가다 = go somewhere else

grammar.explanation: Just need to, all you have to do is
grammar.example: 가면 되니까 = because you can just go

contents.translation: But you'll get fired there too.
Wanna bet?

grammar.example: 할래요? = do you want to do it?

contents.translation: Me?

grammar.explanation: Polite particle, here used to express surprise

contents.original: 홍혜인 씨 부장님한테 혼날 때마다 깜짝깜짝 놀랍니다.
contents.pronunciation: Hong Hyein ssi bujangnim-hante honnal ttaemada kkamjjak-kkamjjak nollam-nida.
contents.translation: Every time you get scolded by the manager, I get startled.

grammar.example: 혼날 때마다 = every time (you) get scolded

contents.original: 도대체 하루에 몇 번까지 혼날 예정입니까?
contents.pronunciation: Dodaeche harue myeot beon-kkaji honnal yejeong-imnikka?
contents.translation: How many times a day are you planning to get scolded?

grammar.explanation: On earth, what in the world (emphasis)

grammar.example: 하루에 몇 번 = how many times a day

grammar.explanation: To be planning to, scheduled to
grammar.example: 혼날 예정 = planning to get scolded

contents.translation: Why are you startled?

grammar.explanation: Soft question ending, asking for explanation

contents.translation: What? / Pardon?

grammar.explanation: Yes, but as a question means 'what?' or 'pardon?'

contents.translation: I'm asking why you're startled.

grammar.example: 놀라냐고요 = I'm asking why you're startled

contents.translation: I'm the one getting scolded, but Mr. Baek Hyeonwoo is startled?
Why?
Think about it carefully. Why that might be.

grammar.example: 한번 생각해봐요 = try thinking about it

contents.culture: This is a classic K-drama line where someone hints at their feelings without directly confessing.

contents.translation: Don't you have an umbrella?

grammar.example: 우산 없어요 = don't have an umbrella

contents.translation: Ah, I don't have one, but...

grammar.example: 없긴 하다 = I don't have one, but...

contents.translation: Use this.
contents.culture: In Korean, 쓰다 means both 'to write' and 'to wear/use' things on your head like umbrellas, hats, glasses.

contents.original: 자꾸 이런 거 얻고 그러니까 내가 더
contents.pronunciation: Jakku ireon geo eotgo geureonikka naega deo
contents.translation: Because I keep receiving things like this, I...
It bothers me. / I can't stop thinking about it.

grammar.explanation: To be bothered by, to be on one's mind

contents.translation: What? / What's this?

grammar.explanation: What is it? (casual, often expressing surprise)

contents.original: 나 때문에 자꾸 놀란다더니 이제는 또 신경쓰인다고 그러네.
contents.pronunciation: Na ttaemune jakku nollan-dadeoni ijeneun tto singyeong-sseuindago geureone.
contents.translation: He said he keeps getting startled because of me, and now he says I'm on his mind.

grammar.example: 놀란다더니 = he said he was startled, and now
신경쓰인다고 그러네 = he says it's on his mind

contents.translation: Miss Hong Hyein.

grammar.explanation: Honorific title after names, like Mr./Ms.

contents.translation: Listen carefully to what I'm about to say.

grammar.explanation: To listen to what someone says
grammar.example: 내 말 들어요 = listen to me

contents.original: 여태는 홍혜인 씨가 부담 가질까 봐 얘기 안 했는데요.
contents.pronunciation: Yeotaeneun Hong Hyein ssi-ga budam gajilkka bwa yaegi an haenneundeyo.
contents.translation: Until now, I didn't say anything because I was worried you'd feel burdened.

grammar.example: 부담 가질까 봐 = worried you'd feel burdened
가질까 봐 = worried that you'd have

contents.translation: Actually, I...
I went to a Seoul university too.

grammar.explanation: To come out, here means 'to graduate from'
grammar.example: 서울대 나왔다 = graduated from Seoul National University

contents.culture: 서울대 나왔다 (went to Seoul National) is a common way to say you graduated from Korea's most prestigious university. Here '서울도 나왔다' implies top-tier education.

contents.translation: Law school at that.

grammar.explanation: At that, on top of that
grammar.example: 그것도 = and on top of that

contents.culture: In Korea, law school (법대) is considered one of the most prestigious and competitive programs, signifying high intelligence and social status.

contents.translation: My family / My house
contents.culture: Koreans commonly use 우리 (our) instead of 내 (my) for family, house, country, etc. It reflects the collectivist culture.

contents.original: 지방이긴 한데 그 마을에선 유지소리 듣는 집이고요.
contents.pronunciation: Jibang-igin hande geu maeul-eseon yuji-sori deunneun jib-igoyo.
contents.translation: It's in the countryside, but we're known as a prominent family in that village.

grammar.explanation: Local notable, influential person in a community
grammar.example: 유지소리 듣다 = to be known as a notable

grammar.explanation: To be called, to be known as
grammar.example: 유지소리 듣다 = known as a local notable

contents.culture: 유지 (influential local figure) refers to a respected, usually wealthy family in rural Korean communities.

contents.translation: For example, we have over 30 cows.
contents.culture: In rural Korea, owning many cattle is a sign of wealth. 30+ cows would indicate a very prosperous farming family.

contents.original: 엊그제 송아지 또 태어나가지고 35마리 육박하는 상황이고.
contents.pronunciation: Eotgeuje songaji tto taeeona-gajigo samshipoh-mari yukbak-haneun sanghwang-igo.
contents.translation: A calf was just born the other day, so we're approaching 35 now.

grammar.explanation: To approach, to be close to (a number)

contents.translation: The officetel I live in now isn't monthly rent either,

grammar.explanation: Officetel - studio apartment that can be used as office

contents.culture: 오피스텔 is a Korean housing type - small studio apartments often used by young professionals. It's a combination of 'office' and 'hotel'.

contents.translation: It's jeonse (lump-sum deposit).

grammar.explanation: Large deposit rental system unique to Korea

contents.culture: 전세 is Korea's unique rental system where you pay a large lump-sum deposit (often 50-80% of property value) instead of monthly rent. Having jeonse money indicates financial stability.

contents.translation: That means I have that much money saved up.

grammar.explanation: Lump sum of money, significant savings
grammar.example: 목돈이 있다 = to have a lump sum

grammar.explanation: It means that, it's saying that
grammar.example: 있다는 얘기 = it means I have

contents.translation: What are you trying to say?

grammar.example: 싶은 건데요 = what is it that you want?

contents.translation: What I'm saying is...
Even if you get fired from your internship and can't find another job,

grammar.example: 인턴 짤리다 = get fired from internship
재취업 안 되다 = can't find another job
안 돼도 = even if it doesn't work

contents.translation: I can take responsibility for you.

grammar.example: 책임질 수 있다 = can take responsibility
책임질 수 있다 = can take responsibility

contents.culture: 책임지다 in romantic context is a serious declaration, often implying marriage intentions. It's a traditional Korean way of proposing commitment.

contents.translation: That's what I'm saying.

grammar.example: 그 얘기요 = that's what I mean

contents.translation: Honestly,
I preferred dual income, but if it's you, Hong Hyein,

grammar.example: 홍혜인 씨라면 = if it's Hong Hyein

contents.translation: I want to try being the sole breadwinner.

grammar.explanation: To handle, to manage, to afford

grammar.example: 감당해보고 싶다 = want to try handling

contents.translation: No, don't feel pressured.

grammar.example: 부담 갖지 마 = don't feel pressured

contents.translation: It's just that I...
I'm doing this because I like you.

grammar.example: 그래요 = that's why I do this

contents.translation: So...
What do you think of me?

grammar.explanation: How is it? What do you think?
grammar.example: 나 어때요 = what do you think of me?

contents.culture: 나 어때요? is a classic indirect confession in Korean dating culture, asking if the other person would consider dating them.

contents.original: 아니 아니 오늘 꼭 대답 안 해도 되고요.
contents.pronunciation: Ani ani oneul kkok daedap an haedo doegoyo.
contents.translation: No no, you don't have to answer today.

grammar.example: 꼭 안 해도 되다 = don't necessarily have to

grammar.explanation: Don't have to, it's okay not to
grammar.example: 대답 안 해도 되다 = don't have to answer

contents.translation: Don't, don't get rained on.

grammar.example: 비 맞지 마 = don't get rained on
맞지 말고 = don't get hit and...

contents.translation: No.
I'm fine, so...

grammar.explanation: To be okay, to be fine

contents.translation: Take it and go.
Mr. Baek Hyeonwoo.
I said I'm fine.
But I...

grammar.explanation: As for me, but I (emphasizing contrast)
grammar.example: 나는요 = but I / as for me

contents.translation: I have a driver.

grammar.example: 기사가 있다 = I have a driver

contents.culture: Having a personal driver (기사) in Korea indicates significant wealth and status, as it's uncommon except for executives and chaebol families.

contents.original: 아무튼 그때부터 백현우 씨는 못 말리는 사랑꾼이었어요.
contents.pronunciation: Amutun geuttae-buteo Baek Hyeonwu ssi-neun mot mallineun sarangkkun-ieosseoyo.
contents.translation: Anyway, from that moment on, Mr. Baek Hyeonwoo was an unstoppable romantic.

grammar.explanation: Someone who's good at romance, a romantic

contents.original: 그렇게 시작된 연애였는데 내가 누구 딸인지 알고 나서 충격받은 그 사람이 사직서를 내고 잠수를 타버리더라고요.
contents.pronunciation: Geureoke sijakdoen yeonae-yeonneunde naega nugu ttal-inji algo naseo chunggyeokbadeun geu sarami sajikseoreul naego jamsureul tabeori-deoragoyo.
contents.translation: That's how our relationship started, but after finding out whose daughter I was, he was so shocked that he submitted his resignation and disappeared.

grammar.explanation: To disappear, go off the radar (lit. 'ride submarine')

contents.culture: 잠수 타다 (literally 'ride a submarine') is Korean slang for disappearing or ghosting someone, often used when someone cuts off all contact.

contents.translation: So.
Baek Hyeonwoo, come out.
That's enough, that's enough.

grammar.explanation: That's enough, stop it, it's done

contents.original: 나 왜 여기에 이렇게 됐을 거야?
contents.pronunciation: Na wae yeogie ireoke dwaesseul geoya?
contents.translation: Why did I end up here like this?

grammar.example: 이렇게 됐다 = ended up like this
됐을 거야 = would have ended up

contents.translation: Back then, was she really like an angel descended from heaven? A goddess?
That's how she looked.

grammar.example: 그렇게 보이다 = to look like that
보였는데 = she looked like that, but...

contents.translation: So you're saying she's not like that now?

grammar.example: 아니란 말씀 = you're saying it's not

contents.translation: No, she's still very much like that.

grammar.explanation: So much, very (originally 'too much' but often means 'very')

contents.translation: Haven't I told you many times?

grammar.example: 드렸지 않습니까 = haven't I told you?

contents.translation: That I'm happy.

contents.original: 아 진짜 저희 정말 잘 살고 있고
contents.pronunciation: A jinjja jeohui jeongmal jal salgo itgo
contents.translation: Really, we're living so well together,

grammar.explanation: To live well, to have a good life

contents.translation: My love for her is the same now as it was then.
I heard Baek Hyeonwoo got divorced.
